awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Behavioral and Environmental Adaptation in Alaska and the Yukon
awd_abstract_narration:
Homo sapiens have successfully colonized the world's most inhospitable regions due in large part to the species' capacity to rapidly adjust behavior in response to changing circumstances. This project aims determine how specific conditions ultimately contributed to past shifts in technology, trade, and diet to build on previous research documenting the extent of human flexibility and resilience. What factors propel important changes to hunter-gatherer subsistence in particularly marginal environments? An archaeological perspective provides a singular opportunity to track the complex relationship between human behavior and shifting external social or climatic conditions by integrating data that spans centuries, hundreds of square miles, and multiple disciplines. Where previous scholarship has focused on the human-environment relationship at distant periods in prehistory or in large-scale societies, few researchers have investigated the causes of recent, well-documented behavioral changes in hunter-gatherers. Incorporating Athabaskan perspectives and engaging Alaskan high-schoolers, this research aims to isolate the driving factors behind a clear and dramatic behavioral shift and concomitant migratory event in the recent pre-Columbian history of Subarctic North America. 

University of Michigan doctoral student Briana Doering will study human-environment relationships by evaluating how hunter-gatherers navigate risk in marginal environments. The work will be conducted in association with researchers from the University of Alaska Fairbanks, Colorado State University, and the University of Arizona. Specifically, this collaborative project will evaluate whether a massive volcanic eruption or population growth resulted in wide-scale shifts in Subarctic hunter-gatherer technology, diet, and trade, and an ultimate southward migration. To explain these behavioral changes, the research team will conduct excavations at four archaeological sites in central Alaska in consultation and collaboration with the descendant Athabaskan community, and study the recovered artifacts using standard statistical analyses and novel geochemical techniques. These material results will then be related to extensive archaeological, climatic, and ecological data from previous investigations in Alaska and Canada with a regional geospatial analysis. This comparative perspective combines uniquely fine-grained social and environmental data from late prehistoric Subarctic archaeological sites to demonstrate the enduring relationship between humans, their environment, and the material traces of human existence at both local and regional scales. Therefore, the results of this broadly applicable research can promote an understanding of hunter-gatherer behavior at other periods and in other regions where only coarse-grained, regional datasets are available. This concerted research will increase our understanding of human resilience generally and Athabaskan subsistence traditions specifically by comparing the knowledge of the descendant community, archaeological materials, and a wealth of fine-grained environmental data to elucidate human behavior in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to improve our understanding of Subarctic North American history and human behavior by conducting archaeological excavations, analyzing artifacts from excavated archaeological sites, and comparing these finds to a broader database of archaeological sites across central Alaska and Yukon, Canada. The project successfully evaluated environmental and social factors that led Dene Athabascans to change their behaviors and culture approximately 1,000 years ago and determined that a prolonged population increase likely drove several cultural shifts and ultimately migration. Previously, archaeologists in the region had suggested that this significant cultural shift was the result of a volcanic eruption ca. 1200 years ago, but this project demonstrated that many aspects of the cultural shift had already begun at the time of the eruption. Instead, linguistic and archaeological evidence suggests that changing group structures may have led to different social organizations that facilitated population growth, resulting in significant changes to material culture reflected in the archaeological record. This project augmented our understanding of Subarctic history and added chronological context to this important cultural transition.

The research completed with support of the NSF also advanced theoretical paradigms related to human decision-making and risk assessment that can be applied in other regions and at other periods in the past. Importantly, this research suggests that highly mobile groups, such as the Dene, may be more resilient to rapid environmental change than they are to prolonged social and demographic change. Archaeologists frequently attribute past cultural change among such highly mobile groups to volcanoes and similarly sudden environmental change. The results of this research project suggests that these environmental conclusions merit additional scruitinty in future studies and may transform the way we conceive of decision-making among past peoples.

The co-PI involved several stakeholders throughout the completion of this research and shared on-going and conclusive results widely. First, representatives of the Healy Lake Village Tribe of central Alaska and the Tanana Chiefs tribal council were consistently briefed on the results of field and lab research, and the co-PI invited a team of local high school students to learn basic archaeological techniques during 10 days of excavation. Second, the co-PI gave several research presentations to elementary and middle schoolers at hands-on science events across the state of Michigan, including at the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History and the Little Traverse Bay Band of Odawa Indians, and is contributing to a remote after school program for middle school students that will be digitally deployed in New Jersey, Ohio, and Alaska in July 2020. Finally, the co-PI presented the research results at state and national anthropology conferences and submitted two manuscripts for publication in peer-reviewed publications, with a third that will be submitted this fall.
